reviewText: This game is great for those people who like the overall planning of the original X-com but didn't like the slow pace of the battles. It takes the same experience and replaces those tactical battles with a space fighter sim. It's definately fun but it's  a bit of a departure from the rest of the series.\n\nIf you are playing on a modern system(xp-recent) then there will be a game breaking bug for this game that will prevent research from completing. THERE IS A FIX FOR THIS and it is a must if you are gonna play it on a modern machine. The thread for it is here: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1722992
voteText: 93 of 100 people (93%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: X-COM: Interceptor is different than most other XCOM games. Instead of being a turn-based ground combat game, it is an amazing real-time space combat game. Like most XCOM games, you have to manage resources, bases, and soldiers (or in this case, pilots). It isn't too well optimized for modern computers and I think the resolution has a maximum of somewhere around 1080x720, but it is still a great game.\n\nThe best part, though, is that it isn't X-COM: Enforcer.
voteText: 29 of 35 people (83%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: I love this game and alway have. Sadly if you are playing on a relatively new machine there will be some game killing bugs. 1) alien data jammers can't be killed. If you try to engage them they just dont show up leaving u in space chasing a radar blip that you can never catch untill u get bored and retreat. Its a pain because they shut down your research and there is nothing you can do about it. 2) pirate bases have the same bug. You can't kill them so get ready to fight suicidal pirate fighter craft every 5 minutes. Not fun. If you have an old rig picking up dust somewhere the sure buy this game and enjoy because it really is a fantastic game. But if you don't then I'd pass.

reviewText: Ahh, Interceptor. A not so great flight sim mixed with a not so great strategic game which somehow when merged together forms a very very playable and very fun (and it's still hard, though easiest out of all the old school X-COM games) game.

reviewText: If u like Xcom and/or flight sim games, then u will probably enjoy this. I thought it was pretty hard at first, but once I figured out how to play, I had a LOT of fun. I think this game is really underrated. It has all of the cool base management of Xcom, but then the battles are real-time flight sim. The campaign is awesome, and I also really like that there's a skirmish mode" that u can create your own custom practice battle and jump right into the action and/or practice your fighting skills if needed. I definitely recommend! =)"
voteText: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I hear so much hate for Interceptor, but it really is unique. I've never encountered an X-Wing style game where you also control the strategic side. After all those times you were hideously outgunned, or had completely the wrong warheads etc on X-Wing, TIE Fighter etc, it's nice to be able to do something about that. Now it's YOUR job to make sure your craft are up to spec. Also ties UFO, TFTD and Apoc together nicely, and hey its a great game in it's own right. Yes, it isn't the game everyone expected when a new X-Com game was announced back in 1997, but it's a worthy addition to the series.

reviewText:
A new gamestyle unlike the original three X-Com games, and much easier to play!

This game actually has options, and gives you tips/controls on how to play. Although the menu screen is a bit confusing, once you get the hang of it it's pretty simple.

When intercepting aliens, the game turns into a first person jet-pilot view much like StarFox where you and your squad (if choosen) hunt down ufos.

Much better gameplay! Except I couldn't for the life of me figure out how to quit the damn game. I had to go into Task Manager...

5/10

reviewText:
I can not recommend this game, on the other hand I can not not recommend this game. It's... complicated.
Before I start explaining, let me link this XKCD[imgs.xkcd.com] comic.

X-COM interceptor is a bad game, but in some peculiar way, enjoyable. Put simply: it's so bad it's good.
I can not in good faith recommend it, because it's bad, on the other hand I can't not recommend it, because it's possible that you may enjoy it.

On strategic side, it's a typical X-COM styled game, adapted to specific environment. You build bases, expand them with modules, research techs (story-wise you download them from Galactic Science Corps, gameplay wise it's just like research in every other such game), you hire pilots, buy craft, weapons and equipment, and send them to intercept UFOs.

Combat is centred about classic dogfighting, with air drag"
date: max speed and other such elements which are staple of oldschool dogfighting
recommended: but make no sense in space. Not that it's unusual for "space" flight sim
hoursPlayed: a lot are guilty of that and it's not necessarily a bad thing.\nWord of warning
voteText: combat is very fast paced
helpfulPercent: so fast that it takes some time to get used to. That's not a problem though
votesHelpful: your wingmen are very capable and will win fights for you
votesTotal: until you start carrying your own weight.\n\nThat's about facts
votesFunny: but what makes it enjoyable?\nHard to say
column16: reading "news from Earth" will make you groan or facepalm
column17: interface is clunky because it pretends to be retro-futuristic in-universe screens/displays
column18: combat repetitive and simplistic which leaks into strategic layer also making it simplistic.\nStill
column20: individual missions rarely take more then minute
column21: big chunk of which is "fly in"
column23: and this is probably what saves Interceptor: it's too short to bore you (too much).\n\nAll in all
column25: I give negative review because it's bad
column26: but I did enjoy it in a way
column27:
maybe you will too?



Side note: there's a bug that makes enemy installations impossible to kill

column30: hence so low value - contrary to what Steam says
column31: I did play game from start to end."

reviewText:
X-COM is remembered by many old-school gamers as the uber-difficult, tactic-heavy, turn-based strategy game of earth's defense against aliens.

While it is still all of these things, it is very difficult to play this game today when there exists the new X-COM games with modern day conveniences. If you've played this game before, it may still get a playthrough thanks to nostalgia. However, if you have never played this game before, it is doubtful that you will both understand how to play this game, nor find it worthwhile to actually play through it. Not to mention, Interceptor was probably the weakest of all the original X-COM games.

While it may not really have stood the test of time to be playable to the masses, it is a title that will always be remembered by those who enjoyed it many years ago.

4/10 Not worth playing today""

Maybe I just suck but if the first mission of the game is just enemies running circles around me can't imagine it gets better.

reviewText: I used to play the Demo Version of this game on the Descent Freespace PC Gamer CD-ROM & it's still the best game even in its Full Version Format. Build your Space Colonies, Research Tech & Enlist Pliots as you take on the Alien Invaders in this 4th Installment of the X-COM Series that is made for MS-DOS & Windows 95/98/2000 & XP 32-Bit PCs.
